review.title: Variable Forgetting in Reasoning about Knowledge
review.abstract: In this paper, we investigate knowledge reasoning within a simple framework called knowledge structure. We use variable forgetting as a basic operation for one agent to reason about its own or other agents\ knowledge. In our framework, two notions namely agents\ observable variables and the weakest sufficient condition play important roles in knowledge reasoning. Given a background knowledge base and a set of observable variables for each agent, we show that the notion of an agent knowing a formula can be defined as a weakest sufficient condition of the formula under background knowledge base. Moreover, we show how to capture the notion of common knowledge by using a generalized notion of weakest sufficient condition. Also, we show that public announcement operator can be conveniently dealt with via our notion of knowledge structure. Further, we explore the computational complexity of the problem whether an epistemic formula is realized in a knowledge structure. In the general case, this problem is PSPACE-hard; however, for some interesting subcases, it can be reduced to co-NP. Finally, we discuss possible applications of our framework in some interesting domains such as the automated analysis of the well-known muddy children puzzle and the verification of the revised Needham-Schroeder protocol. We believe that there are many scenarios where the natural presentation of the available information about knowledge is under the form of a knowledge structure. What makes it valuable compared with the corresponding multi-agent S5 Kripke structure is that it can be much more succinct.

sections.heading: 7. A Case Study: the Muddy Children Puzzle
sections.text: In this section, using the example of the mud child puzzle, we show how our framework can be applied to practical problems.

sections.heading: 7.1 Muddy Children Puzzle
sections.text: The mud children's riddle is a well-known variant of the sage's riddle. The story goes like this (Fagin et al., 1995): Imagine n children playing together. Some of the children, say k of them, get mud on their foreheads. Each of them sees the mud on others, but not on his own forehead. Then comes the father who says: "At least one of you has mud on his forehead." The father then asks the following question over and over again: "Does any of you know if he has mud on his own forehead?" Assuming that all the children are perceptive, intelligent, truthful and answer at the same time, we want to show that the first (k − 1) time the father asks the question, they will say "no," but the next time the children with muddy foreheads will all answer "yes."

sections.heading: 8. Application to Verification of Security Protocols
sections.text: In this section, we apply our knowledge model to the verification of security protocols. Security protocols that set up participant credits and deal with the distribution of cryptographic keys are essential for communication over vulnerable networks. Authentication plays a key role in security protocols. Subtle errors that lead to attacks are often found when the protocols are used for many years. This presents a challenge in demonstrating the correctness of a security protocol. Formal methods are introduced to determine and prove whether a secure protocol meets a specific authentication specification.

sections.heading: 8.1 Background on Authentication Protocols
sections.text: Authentication protocols aim to coordinate the activity of different parties (usually referred to as principals) over a network. They typically consist of a sequence of message exchange programs whose format is pre-defined and needs to be adapted to. Normally, a principal can participate in a protocol that is executed in different ways, as an initiator or responder; we often call the principal different roles. Very often, a principal can participate in multiple protocols simultaneously with different routines.Authentication protocol developers need to be aware that the message can be intercepted and someone with malicious intent can impersonate an honest principal. One of the key problems with authentication is ensuring confidentiality, that is to prevent private information from being passed on to unauthorized entities. Another problem is encryption, which protects the intruder from the identity of other principals.

sections.heading: 8.2 The Dolev-Yao Intruder Model
sections.text: The standard model of the adversary for the analysis of security protocols was introduced by Dolev and Yao in 1983 and is commonly known as the Dolev-Yao model (Dolev & Yao, 1983), according to which a number of conservative assumptions are made as follows: 1. Messages are considered as indivisible abstract values and not as bit sequences; 2. All messages of one principle to all other principles must pass through the adversary and the adversary acts in communication as a general router; 3. The adversary can read, modify and redirect any message; 4. The adversary can only decrypt a message if he has the right keys and only compose new messages from keys and messages he already has; 5. The adversary cannot carry out statistical or other cryptanalytic attacks; although this model has the disadvantage of finding implementation-dependent attacks, it simplifies protocol analysis; it has proven to be the most powerful modeling of the adversary (Cervesato, 2001) because it can simulate other possible attackers.

sections.text: The BAN logic (Burrows, Abadi, & Needham, 1990) is one of the most successful logical tools for thinking about security protocols, but the semantics of the BAN are always debatable, and it is not clear under what assumption the rules of BAN logic are solid and complete, which motivated the search for more appropriate frameworks (models).The advantage of our approach is that we use knowledge structures as semantic models to verify the veracity of epistemic objectives for security protocols.An important problem is that in the face of a security protocol, where and how the corresponding knowledge structure comes from, which corresponds to a security protocol, we have developed a semantic model of the corresponding security protocol and the corresponding underlying structure of the security protocol.

sections.heading: 9. Related Work
sections.text: There are a number of approaches dealing with the concept of variable forgetting or the elimination of means (Boole, 1854) in several contexts: the concept of variable forgetting was formally defined in the propository and first-order logic of Lin and Reiter (1994); in recent years, theories of forgetting have been proposed under the concept of programmable semantics (Zhang & Foo, 2006; Eiter & Wang, 2008); forgetting has also been generalized in the logic of description (Kontchakov, Wolter, & Zakharyashev, 2008; Wang, Topor, & Pan, 2008; Kontchakov, Walther, & Wolter, 2009).

sections.heading: 10. Conclusion
sections.text: The main contribution of this paper is as follows: First, we have examined knowledge thinking within a simple framework called the knowledge structure, which consists of a global knowledge base and a set of observable variables for each agent. Therefore, the concept of knowledge structure can be used as a semantic model for a multi-agent logic of knowledge and general knowledge. In this model, the calculation of knowledge and general knowledge can be reduced to the functioning of variable forgetfulness; furthermore, an objective formula known by agents in states when one of their weakest sufficient conditions is held on Oi. Second, in order to grasp the notion of common knowledge within our framework, we have generalized and preserved the notion of the weakest sufficient conditions for a set of propositional variables having the notion of the weakest V-sufficient conditions. In view of a set of agents and a family V, we expect that we will have variable sets of these agents, we have demonstrated that an objective ability is the formula of a common knowledge, the formula of an objective knowledge in relation to a general knowledge structure.

metadata.abstractText: In this paper, we investigate knowledge reasoning within a simple framework called knowledge structure. We use variable forgetting as a basic operation for one agent to reason about its own or other agents’ knowledge. In our framework, two notions namely agents’ observable variables and the weakest sufficient condition play important roles in knowledge reasoning. Given a background knowledge base Γ and a set of observable variables Oi for each agent i, we show that the notion of agent i knowing a formula φ can be defined as a weakest sufficient condition of φ over Oi under Γ. Moreover, we show how to capture the notion of common knowledge by using a generalized notion of weakest sufficient condition. Also, we show that public announcement operator can be conveniently dealt with via our notion of knowledge structure. Further, we explore the computational complexity of the problem whether an epistemic formula is realized in a knowledge structure. In the general case, this problem is PSPACE-hard; however, for some interesting subcases, it can be reduced to co-NP. Finally, we discuss possible applications of our framework in some interesting domains such as the automated analysis of the well-known muddy children puzzle and the verification of the revised Needham-Schroeder protocol. We believe that there are many scenarios where the natural presentation of the available information about knowledge is under the form of a knowledge structure. What makes it valuable compared with the corresponding multi-agent S5 Kripke structure is that it can be much more succinct.
